questions.neutral: You look like you dodged something - true?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I explore the city's underground. It's a different world down there.
neutral_answer: Yeah, it was a weird night. Made it out all right.
Spent some time wandering for my own good.
My hobby's poking around old places, city never runs out.
Blackout made things interesting.
You could say I found a bit of quiet underground.
Hobby of mine—exploring forgotten tunnels. Been at it for years.
City blackout meant nobody watching, for once.
Kept my head down, left no trace behind.
Don't usually get it that peaceful.
Not the worst thing to dodge, honestly. Blackouts thin out the noise.
My thing is urban exploring—mostly tunnels, sometimes old data centers.
Last night, power out, I went deeper than usual. Quiet down there.
No surveillance, just echoes and old tech—felt different.
Sometimes a flask and a flashlight is all you need down there.
Beats sitting around waiting for Council updates.
Yeah, dodged more than traffic. City's pulse just... stopped last night.
I explore city utility tunnels—call it a hobby, call it habit.
Used to be watched, every step. Not this time—total blackout.
Stumbled across handwritten logs from pre-BCI days, dusty but familiar.
Felt like time-travel, no algorithms, just pipes and steel and memory.
Funny thing—ran into some neighbors organizing supplies underground.
No one cared about scores, just getting by together.
You nailed it, Alex. Been doing urban exploration since before the BCI days.
My favorite spots are city tunnels and locked data vaults—half curiosity, half necessity now.
This blackout? Gift-wrapped for people like me. No cameras, no warnings, just the creak of old doors.
Took a tipple, wandered deeper than usual—found a pre-BCI maintenance log, real handwriting.
Felt like connecting to lost voices down there. Almost freeing, honestly.
You see, back when Marek ran things, I kept my head low but my ears open.
Underground last night, ran into a supply group—ordinary folks, forgetting their scores.
Makes you remember this city isn’t all about numbers, even if it pretends.
hobby_answer: Yeah, never sleep. Always something interesting underground.
Harder now with everything blacked out. No lights, no network, no rules.
Ran into a few more folks than I like lately.
People get jumpy when the system's broken.
Yeah, never sleep. Keeps me busy, especially these days.
Every tunnel's open now with the blackout. Not always a good thing.
Last run, stumbled onto others gathering supplies.
Folks are suddenly real interested in old shortcuts and basements.
Less privacy for explorers, more headaches from the chaos.
Yeah, never sleep. Especially when the city forgets to lock the doors.
Past few weeks, blackout means I get places no scanner could ever let me.
Used to have to dodge cameras. Now it’s just flashlights and actual locks.
Seen more locals down there, organizing, trading, getting by.
Strange seeing tunnels busier than the streets up top.
Feels almost pre-BCI down there these nights.
Yeah, never sleep. The tunnels are practically home by now.
Since blackout, those ducts became the city’s new commons.
Whole scenes form below—locals meeting, helping, bartering, right underneath Council’s nose.
Last Friday, I shared a drink with strangers instead of dodging sensors.
Hadn’t happened in a decade or more.
Funny—when the city’s systems break, people remember the old ways.
Sometimes I even forget my score down there.
Yeah, never sleep. My first adventure was under the city library, age fifteen.
Been drawn to closed doors and locked panels ever since.
Blackout turned every system cave into a crossroads—everyone’s in on the secret now.
Met a neighbor I hadn’t spoken to in five years in old telecom duct.
We traded stories, some cans, even local news.
Nobody checked scores, or asked affiliations. Just people, trying to keep warm.
Reminded me how, before BCI, you didn’t need permission to move.
Now every outing’s risky, but oddly freeing—no model watching me think.
Sometimes wonder if this is what real freedom feels like... or just temporary confusion.
